canonical_explanation.text: Heat is a form of energy that flows from a hotter object to a cooler object. Temperature is the measure of the degree of hotness or coldness of a body. We use thermometers to measure temperature accurately. A clinical thermometer is used to measure body temperature and has a range of 35 degrees C to 42 degrees C with a kink that prevents mercury from falling back. A laboratory thermometer has a range of -10 degrees C to 110 degrees C and is used for measuring temperatures in experiments. Heat can be transferred in three ways: conduction (through solids, without the material moving), convection (through liquids and gases, with the material moving), and radiation (through empty space, without any medium). Materials that conduct heat easily are called conductors (metals like iron, copper, aluminium), and those that do not are called insulators (wood, plastic, air, wool). Woollen clothes keep us warm because wool traps air, which is a poor conductor of heat. Dark-coloured objects absorb more heat than light-coloured objects.
rules: Heat flows from a hotter body to a cooler body.
Temperature measures the degree of hotness or coldness.
Clinical thermometer: range 35C to 42C, has a kink, measures body temperature.
Laboratory thermometer: range -10C to 110C, used in experiments.
Conduction: transfer of heat through a material without the material itself moving (mainly in solids).
Convection: transfer of heat by actual movement of the heated material (mainly in liquids and gases).
Radiation: transfer of heat without any medium, through electromagnetic waves.
Conductors: materials that allow heat to pass through easily (metals).
Insulators: materials that do not allow heat to pass through easily (wood, plastic, air, wool).
Dark-coloured objects absorb and emit more heat than light-coloured objects.
Woollen clothes trap air, which is a poor conductor, keeping us warm.
Sea breeze and land breeze are examples of convection.

questions.question_text: Heat always flows from a:

options.text: Cooler object to a hotter object
Hotter object to a cooler object
Bigger object to a smaller object
Smaller object to a bigger object

questions.explanation_correct: Heat always flows naturally from a body at higher temperature (hotter) to a body at lower temperature (cooler). This continues until both bodies reach the same temperature (thermal equilibrium).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heat transfer depends on temperature difference, not size. Heat flows from hotter to cooler objects, regardless of their size.

questions.question_text: Temperature is a measure of the:

options.text: Amount of matter in an object
Degree of hotness or coldness of a body
Amount of heat in a body

questions.explanation_correct: Temperature is the measure of the degree of hotness or coldness of a body. It tells us how hot or cold something is but does not measure the total amount of heat energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Temperature specifically measures how hot or cold a body is. It is not the same as mass, weight, or the total amount of heat.

questions.question_text: Our sense of touch is a reliable way to measure temperature.
questions.explanation_correct: Our sense of touch is not reliable for measuring temperature. It can be misleading. For example, if one hand is in hot water and the other in cold water, and then both are placed in warm water, they will give different sensations. A thermometer is needed for accurate measurement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Touch is subjective and unreliable. A thermometer provides an accurate, objective measurement of temperature.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of temperature is ___ (or Kelvin).
questions.explanation_correct: Temperature is commonly measured in degree Celsius (also written as degrees C). Kelvin is the SI base unit, but degree Celsius is the most commonly used unit in everyday and school-level physics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'degree Celsius'. It is the most commonly used unit for measuring temperature.

questions.question_text: The range of a clinical thermometer is:
questions.explanation_correct: A clinical thermometer is designed to measure human body temperature, which normally ranges from about 35 degrees C to 42 degrees C. This range covers normal body temperature (37 degrees C) and fever temperatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A clinical thermometer has a limited range of 35 to 42 degrees C, designed specifically for body temperature. -10 to 110 degrees C is the range of a laboratory thermometer.

questions.question_text: Why does a clinical thermometer have a kink (constriction) near the bulb?

options.text: To make it look different from a laboratory thermometer
To prevent the mercury from flowing back immediately, allowing the reading to be taken after removal from the body
To make the mercury rise faster

questions.explanation_correct: The kink in a clinical thermometer prevents the mercury from flowing back into the bulb immediately after removing it from the patient's body. This allows the doctor or nurse to read the temperature at leisure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The kink serves a practical purpose: it prevents mercury from retreating back to the bulb after the thermometer is removed from the patient, allowing a stable reading to be taken.

questions.question_text: A laboratory thermometer has a range of ___ degrees C to ___ degrees C.
questions.explanation_correct: A laboratory thermometer has a wider range (-10 degrees C to 110 degrees C) compared to a clinical thermometer, as it needs to measure a variety of temperatures in experiments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '-10, 110'. The laboratory thermometer covers a much wider range than the clinical thermometer.

questions.question_text: A laboratory thermometer should never be used to measure body temperature.
questions.explanation_correct: A laboratory thermometer should not be used to measure body temperature. It does not have a kink, so the mercury falls back immediately, making it hard to read. It is also not designed for clinical use and could be unsafe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. A laboratory thermometer lacks the kink needed for clinical use and is not designed or safe for measuring body temperature.

questions.question_text: Heat transfer through a solid material without the material itself moving is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Conduction is the process of heat transfer through a material where heat passes from particle to particle without the particles themselves moving from their positions. It mainly occurs in solids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convection involves actual movement of the material (in liquids and gases). Radiation does not need any medium. Conduction is the transfer of heat through a solid without the material moving.

questions.question_text: Heat transfer in liquids and gases occurs mainly by:
questions.explanation_correct: In liquids and gases, heat transfer occurs mainly by convection. The heated fluid becomes lighter (less dense) and rises, while the cooler fluid sinks. This creates a circulation called convection current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While conduction can occur in liquids, it is very slow. The main mode of heat transfer in liquids and gases is convection, where the heated material itself moves.

questions.question_text: Which mode of heat transfer does not require any medium?
questions.explanation_correct: Radiation is the mode of heat transfer that does not require any medium. Heat can travel through empty space (vacuum) by radiation. This is how heat from the Sun reaches the Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conduction requires a solid medium and convection requires a fluid medium. Only radiation can transfer heat through a vacuum (empty space).

questions.question_text: Heat from the Sun reaches the Earth by the process of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Heat from the Sun travels through the vacuum of space to reach the Earth. Since there is no medium in space, neither conduction nor convection can work. The heat reaches us through radiation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'radiation'. The space between the Sun and Earth is mostly vacuum, and only radiation can transfer heat without a medium.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a good conductor of heat?
questions.explanation_correct: Copper is a metal and metals are good conductors of heat. Heat passes through copper very quickly. That is why cooking utensils are often made of copper or aluminium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wood, plastic, and rubber are poor conductors (insulators) of heat. Copper, being a metal, is an excellent conductor of heat.

questions.question_text: Materials that do not allow heat to pass through them easily are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Materials that do not allow heat to pass through them easily are called insulators (or poor conductors). Examples include wood, plastic, wool, air, and rubber.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conductors allow heat to pass through easily. Materials that resist heat transfer are called insulators.

questions.question_text: Air is a good conductor of heat.
questions.explanation_correct: Air is a poor conductor (insulator) of heat. It does not allow heat to pass through it easily by conduction. This is why trapped air in materials like wool, fur, and double-glazed windows provides insulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Air is a poor conductor of heat (an insulator). This property makes trapped air useful for thermal insulation.

questions.question_text: Woollen clothes keep us warm in winter because:

options.text: Wool traps air, which is a poor conductor of heat
Wool absorbs cold from the surroundings
Wool is a good conductor of heat

questions.explanation_correct: Woollen clothes have spaces between their fibres that trap air. Air is a poor conductor of heat, so the trapped air prevents body heat from escaping to the cold surroundings, keeping us warm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wool does not generate heat or absorb cold. It keeps us warm because its fibres trap pockets of air, which being a poor conductor, prevents our body heat from escaping.

questions.question_text: Dark-coloured objects absorb more heat from radiation than light-coloured objects.
questions.explanation_correct: Dark-coloured objects are better absorbers of heat radiation than light-coloured objects. This is why wearing dark clothes in summer makes us feel hotter, while light-coloured clothes reflect more heat and keep us cooler.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Dark colours absorb more heat, while light colours reflect more heat. This is why light-coloured clothes are preferred in summer.

questions.question_text: We wear ___ coloured clothes in summer because they reflect more heat.
questions.explanation_correct: Light-coloured (white or light) clothes reflect most of the heat radiation falling on them, keeping us cooler in summer. Dark-coloured clothes would absorb more heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'light'. Light-coloured clothes reflect heat radiation, while dark-coloured clothes absorb it.

questions.question_text: When water is heated in a pot, the hot water rises up and cold water moves down. This creates a ___ current.
questions.explanation_correct: When water is heated, the heated water at the bottom becomes less dense and rises, while the cooler, denser water from above sinks to take its place. This circular movement is called a convection current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'convection'. The movement of heated water rising and cool water sinking creates a convection current.

questions.question_text: Why do cooking pans have wooden or plastic handles?

options.text: Because wood and plastic are poor conductors of heat, preventing burns
Because wood and plastic are stronger than metal

questions.explanation_correct: Cooking pan handles are made of wood or plastic because these materials are poor conductors (insulators) of heat. They do not transfer heat from the pan to our hands, preventing burns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The handles are made of insulators for safety: wood and plastic do not conduct heat, so we can hold the pan without burning our hands.

questions.question_text: The normal human body temperature is:
questions.explanation_correct: The normal human body temperature is approximately 37 degrees C (or 98.6 degrees F). A temperature significantly above this, such as 38 degrees C or more, usually indicates a fever.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Normal body temperature is about 37 degrees C. 42 degrees C would be a dangerously high fever, and 35 degrees C would indicate hypothermia.

questions.question_text: Before using a clinical thermometer, you should shake it so that the mercury level falls below:
questions.explanation_correct: Before use, you shake the clinical thermometer to bring the mercury below 35 degrees C (the lowest mark on the scale). This ensures an accurate reading for the new measurement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mercury must be brought below 35 degrees C, which is the lower limit of the clinical thermometer's scale. This is done by shaking or jerking the thermometer.

questions.question_text: When you hold one end of a metal spoon in a hot cup of tea, the other end eventually becomes hot. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Heat travels through the solid metal spoon from the hot end (in tea) to the cooler end (in your hand) by conduction. The metal particles vibrate more as they receive heat and pass it along to neighbouring particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heat moving through a solid material (the metal spoon) from one end to the other is conduction. The spoon itself does not move; heat is transferred through particle-to-particle vibration.

questions.question_text: Sea breeze occurs during the day because:

options.text: The sea water heats up faster than the land
The land heats up faster than the sea, hot air rises from the land, and cool air from the sea moves in
The wind always blows from sea to land
Sea water pushes air towards the land

questions.explanation_correct: During the day, land heats up faster than the sea. Hot air above the land rises (being less dense), creating a low pressure area. The cooler air from above the sea rushes in to fill this gap, creating a sea breeze. This is an example of convection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sea breeze is caused by the differential heating of land and sea. Land heats up faster, causing hot air to rise, and the cooler sea air moves in to replace it. This is a convection current.

questions.question_text: Ravi places a metal spoon, a plastic spoon, and a wooden spoon in a cup of hot water. Which one will feel hottest at the handle after some time?
questions.explanation_correct: The metal spoon will feel hottest because metal is a good conductor of heat. Heat from the hot water travels quickly through the metal to the handle. Plastic and wood are poor conductors, so their handles remain relatively cool.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metal conducts heat much faster than plastic or wood. The metal spoon's handle gets hot quickly, while plastic and wooden handles stay cool because they are insulators.

questions.question_text: Why do birds fluff up their feathers in cold weather?

options.text: To look bigger and scare predators
To trap more air between feathers, which acts as an insulator
Because their feathers grow in cold weather

questions.explanation_correct: By fluffing up their feathers, birds trap more air between the layers of feathers. Air is a poor conductor of heat (insulator), so the trapped air reduces heat loss from their bodies, keeping them warm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Birds fluff up feathers to trap air for insulation, not for display, growth, or sun absorption. The trapped air acts as a poor conductor, preventing body heat from escaping.

questions.question_text: When you feel the warmth of a bonfire from a distance, the heat reaches you mainly by radiation.
questions.explanation_correct: When you stand at a distance from a bonfire and feel warm, the heat reaches you mainly through radiation. Radiation does not require any medium and can travel through air to reach you directly from the fire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The heat from a bonfire reaches you at a distance mainly by radiation, which travels in straight lines through air without needing direct contact.

questions.question_text: A laboratory thermometer should be kept upright (vertical) in the liquid being measured. This is because:

options.text: The bulb must be fully immersed in the liquid for accurate reading
The mercury will spill out otherwise
It looks more professional that way

questions.explanation_correct: The laboratory thermometer must be kept upright with its bulb fully immersed in the liquid. This ensures the mercury absorbs heat from the liquid properly and gives an accurate temperature reading.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The bulb needs to be fully immersed in the liquid for accurate heat transfer and reading. This is a practical requirement, not about breaking or appearance.

questions.question_text: Aluminium is a good ___ of heat, which is why it is used to make cooking utensils.
questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium, being a metal, is a good conductor of heat. It transfers heat from the stove to the food quickly and evenly, making it ideal for cooking utensils.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'conductor'. Aluminium conducts heat well, allowing food to cook quickly and evenly.

questions.question_text: Why do we see smoke rising upward from a fire?

options.text: Because smoke is attracted by the sky
Because hot air carrying smoke rises up as it is less dense than the surrounding cooler air
Because smoke is lighter than air

questions.explanation_correct: The hot gases and air produced by the fire are less dense than the surrounding cooler air. Being lighter, they rise upward, carrying the smoke particles with them. This is convection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smoke rises because the hot air and gases from the fire are less dense than the surrounding cooler air. This upward movement due to density difference is a convection current.

questions.question_text: Two thin blankets placed together keep you warmer than one thick blanket of the same total thickness because the air trapped between the blankets acts as an insulator.
questions.explanation_correct: Two thin blankets trap a layer of air between them. Since air is a poor conductor of heat, this trapped air layer provides extra insulation, making two thin blankets warmer than a single thick blanket of the same total weight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The air trapped between the two blankets adds an extra insulating layer, providing better protection from cold than a single blanket.

questions.question_text: A glass of ice water is left on a table in a warm room. After some time, water droplets appear on the outside of the glass. This is because:

options.text: The cold glass cools the warm air around it, causing water vapour to condense on the glass surface
The ice inside pushes water out

questions.explanation_correct: The cold surface of the glass cools the warm, moist air in contact with it. When the air is cooled below its dew point, the water vapour in the air condenses into tiny water droplets on the outside of the glass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water does not leak through glass. The droplets form because the cold glass surface causes water vapour in the surrounding warm air to condense.

questions.question_text: At night, the land cools faster than the sea, so the breeze blows from ___ to ___.
questions.explanation_correct: At night, the land cools faster than the sea. The air above the (warmer) sea rises, and cooler air from the land moves towards the sea to replace it. This is called a land breeze.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'land, sea'. A land breeze blows from land to sea at night because the land cools faster than the sea.

questions.question_text: Why are houses in cold regions built with double-walled construction with air in between?

options.text: The trapped air acts as an insulator, preventing heat from escaping
To make the house look bigger

questions.explanation_correct: Double walls with trapped air provide excellent insulation. Air is a poor conductor of heat, so it prevents the indoor heat from escaping through the walls, keeping the house warm in cold weather.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The purpose of double walls is insulation. The air trapped between the walls acts as a poor conductor, reducing heat loss from the warm interior to the cold exterior.

questions.question_text: Why is the bottom of cooking vessels sometimes blackened?

options.text: Because black surfaces absorb more heat, making cooking faster
Because the manufacturer prefers black colour

questions.explanation_correct: Black or dark surfaces absorb more heat radiation than shiny or light surfaces. By blackening the bottom of a cooking vessel, it absorbs heat from the flame more efficiently, making cooking faster.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A black surface absorbs more heat radiation. This is why the bottoms of some cooking vessels are kept black or dark, to absorb maximum heat and cook food faster.

questions.question_text: While reading a clinical thermometer, it should be held at eye level with the mercury column facing you.
questions.explanation_correct: To take an accurate reading, the thermometer should be held at eye level. The mercury column should face you so that you can read the scale clearly without parallax error.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Holding the thermometer at eye level with the mercury column facing you ensures accurate reading and avoids parallax error.

questions.question_text: In which direction does the air move when a room heater is switched on?

options.text: Hot air moves downward, cold air moves upward
Hot air rises up, cold air moves down and towards the heater
Air does not move at all

questions.explanation_correct: When a room heater is switched on, the air near the heater gets heated, becomes less dense, and rises. The cooler, denser air from other parts of the room moves down and towards the heater to replace it. This sets up a convection current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hot air rises because it becomes less dense, and cold air sinks and moves towards the heat source. This circulation (convection current) gradually warms the entire room.

questions.question_text: A thermos flask reduces heat transfer by conduction, convection, and ___ to keep liquids hot or cold for a long time.
questions.explanation_correct: A thermos flask is designed to minimise all three modes of heat transfer. The vacuum between its double walls prevents conduction and convection, and the silvered (shiny) surfaces reduce heat loss by radiation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'radiation'. A thermos flask uses vacuum (preventing conduction and convection) and silvered surfaces (reducing radiation) to minimise heat transfer.

questions.question_text: Priya dips her left hand in ice water and right hand in warm water for one minute. Then she puts both hands in water at room temperature. Her left hand will feel ___ and her right hand will feel ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The left hand (from ice water) will feel the room temperature water as warm because it is warmer than the ice water. The right hand (from warm water) will feel the same room temperature water as cold. This demonstrates that touch is an unreliable way to judge temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sensation depends on the previous temperature. After ice water, room temperature feels warm. After warm water, room temperature feels cold. This shows our senses can be misleading.

questions.question_text: Give two differences between a clinical thermometer and a laboratory thermometer.

options.text: Clinical: range 35-42C, has kink; Laboratory: range -10 to 110C, no kink
Clinical: range -10 to 110C, no kink; Laboratory: range 35-42C, has kink
Both have the same range but different colours
Both have kinks but different lengths

questions.explanation_correct: The clinical thermometer has a narrow range (35-42 degrees C) and a kink near the bulb that prevents mercury from falling back. The laboratory thermometer has a wider range (-10 to 110 degrees C) and no kink.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Clinical thermometers have a limited range suited for body temperature (35-42C) and include a kink. Laboratory thermometers have a wider range (-10 to 110C) and no kink.

questions.question_text: A student places a drop of ink at the bottom of a beaker of cold water and then heats the beaker from below. The ink will:

options.text: Move upward with the hot water and then circulate as a convection current

questions.explanation_correct: When heated from below, the water at the bottom gets hot, becomes less dense, and rises, carrying the ink with it. The cooler water moves down. This creates a visible convection current that the ink helps to trace.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ink traces the convection current: hot water at the bottom rises (carrying the ink up), and cool water sinks. This is a common experiment to demonstrate convection.

questions.question_text: Explain why an ice cream seller wraps his ice cream container in a thick cloth or blanket.

options.text: The cloth is a poor conductor that prevents heat from reaching the ice cream
The cloth keeps the ice cream frozen by generating cold
The cloth is a good conductor that draws heat away from the ice cream

questions.explanation_correct: A thick cloth or blanket acts as a thermal insulator. It prevents the surrounding warm air from transferring heat to the cold ice cream, slowing down melting. The cloth does not generate cold; it simply blocks heat transfer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cloth acts as an insulator, preventing outside heat from reaching the ice cream. It does not generate cold or conduct heat away. It slows heat transfer from the warm surroundings.

questions.question_text: Ventilators (openings near the roof) are provided in rooms for which purpose related to heat transfer?

options.text: To allow conduction of heat through the walls
To allow hot air to escape by convection, since hot air rises to the top
To make the room look bigger

questions.explanation_correct: Hot air is less dense and rises to the top of a room. Ventilators placed near the roof allow this hot air to escape, and fresh cooler air enters from below (through windows and doors). This is based on the principle of convection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ventilators are placed high up because hot air rises (convection). They allow the hot air to escape from the top while cooler air enters from lower openings, keeping the room cool.

questions.question_text: Penguins huddle together in cold weather to reduce the total surface area exposed to cold wind, thereby reducing heat loss.
questions.explanation_correct: By huddling together, penguins reduce their total exposed surface area. Less exposed surface means less heat loss by radiation and convection to the cold air. The penguins in the middle of the huddle stay the warmest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Huddling reduces the surface area exposed to cold wind and reduces heat loss, helping penguins survive extreme cold.

questions.question_text: In a desert, days are very hot but nights are very cold. This is because:

options.text: Sand is a good conductor of heat
Sand heats up and cools down very quickly as it is a poor conductor and has low specific heat
There is no Sun at night
Deserts are at a higher altitude

questions.explanation_correct: Sand heats up very quickly during the day (getting very hot) and cools down quickly at night (getting very cold). This is because sand has a low specific heat capacity and does not retain heat well. The lack of moisture and vegetation also contributes to extreme temperature variations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The extreme temperature difference in deserts is mainly because sand heats up and cools down very quickly. It does not retain heat, leading to very hot days and very cold nights.

questions.question_text: Igloos made of ice blocks keep Eskimos warm because ice is a poor ___ of heat and the trapped air inside provides insulation.
questions.explanation_correct: Ice is a poor conductor of heat, just like snow. The ice walls of an igloo, along with the trapped air inside, prevent the body heat of the people inside from escaping to the extremely cold outside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'conductor'. Ice and the air trapped within it are poor conductors, providing insulation in an igloo.

questions.question_text: On a hot summer day, which of the following combinations would keep you the coolest?
questions.explanation_correct: Light-coloured clothes reflect more heat radiation, keeping you cooler. Loose-fitting clothes allow air circulation, which helps evaporation of sweat and does not trap heat against the body. This combination provides maximum cooling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light colours reflect heat (not absorb), and loose clothes allow air circulation and sweat evaporation. The combination of light colour and loose fit provides the best cooling effect.

questions.question_text: A metal rod and a wooden rod of the same length are exposed to fire at one end. Which statement is correct?

options.text: Both rods conduct heat at the same rate
The metal rod conducts heat faster, so its other end becomes hot sooner
The wooden rod conducts heat faster

questions.explanation_correct: Metal is a good conductor of heat, so the heat from the fire travels quickly through the metal rod and the other end becomes hot sooner. Wood is a poor conductor, so the wooden rod transfers heat much more slowly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metal conducts heat much faster than wood. The metal rod's far end will become hot quickly, while the wooden rod's far end will remain relatively cool for a long time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements correctly distinguishes between heat and temperature?

options.text: Heat and temperature are the same thing
Heat is the total energy transferred; temperature is the degree of hotness
Temperature is always greater than heat
Heat is measured in degrees Celsius

questions.explanation_correct: Heat is the form of energy that is transferred between objects due to a temperature difference. Temperature is the measure of the degree of hotness or coldness of an object. Heat is measured in Joules, while temperature is measured in degrees Celsius or Kelvin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heat and temperature are different concepts. Heat is energy transferred (measured in Joules), while temperature measures hotness/coldness (measured in degrees). They are related but not the same.

questions.question_text: The maximum temperature a clinical thermometer can measure is ___ degrees C, and a reading above 37 degrees C in a person generally indicates ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A clinical thermometer has an upper limit of 42 degrees C. The normal human body temperature is 37 degrees C, and any reading above this generally indicates that the person has a fever.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answers are '42' and 'fever'. The clinical thermometer measures up to 42 degrees C, and body temperature above the normal 37 degrees C indicates fever.
